description: Barry Weisberg interviews a representative of the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA). He is wanted by the Portugese authorities and cannot reveal his name. He discusses the history of Angola as a Portugese colony and his efforts with the MPLA to overthrow the colonial regime of Portugal. Both the Portugese and the U.S. roles are described, as well as the goals and background of the MPLA. Recorded for Pacifica in Paris.
title: The Struggle for the Liberation of Angola, Part 1

description: Traces the change of Afrikaner clergyman Beyers Naudé from an ardent supporter of apartheid to an anti-apartheid activist. Touches on the Sharpeville massacre and the killings of Steve Biko and Fabian Ribeiro.
title: The cry of reason : Beyers Naudé : an Afrikaner speaks out

notes.note: written and directed by Robert Bilheimer ; produced by Robert Bilheimer, Ronald Mix ; co-produced and directed by Kevin Harris ; associate producer, Heidi Ostertag.
"A production of Worldwide Documentaries, Inc. in association with the Phelps-Stokes Fund."
Logo "The Film House Group" appears before film.

Cinematography, Ron Mix (U.S.A. and Europe), Dewalt Aukema, Peter Tischauser, Andre Pienaar (South Africa) ; editor, William Tadler ; original music composed and performed by Abdullah Ibrahim (Dollar Brand).

Contributors: T. S. Farisani (Evangelical Lutheran Church) ; Mamphela Ramphele (University of Cape Town) ; Desmond Tutu (Archbishop of Cape Town) ; Allan Boesak (World Alliance of Reformed Churches) ; Frank Chikane (South African Council of Churches). Narrator: Mark Mathabane.

description: In South Africa, the black artist has attempted to express the anguish and suffering of his people. Most of his work is banned in South Africa and often he has been forced into exile. His writing is powerful and poignant, and accurately portrays the black man's life in South Africa today. Readers: Dennis Brutus, Dolores Hayden, Jeannie McCormick, Frederick Wranovics, Diana Ekman, and Stephen Schwartz. Production by Ron Richards
title: Reactions to Tyranny: the Black Artist in South Africa

table_of_contents: Reel 1. Tiv division: Gboko. (1966, b & w.) -- Three women's dances. -- Reel 2. Jos plateau : Miango. (1966, b & w.) -- Four Irigwe men's dances : Dogo dangana; Neriga; Rubwo dombo; Rage udu. -- no. 3. Kamberi dances, Yauri Emirate, North West State. (1970, color, 13.33 min.) -- Tungun Bindige village : Maranji dance ; Akiapu dance. -- Dances performed at Gebbi town : Maranji dance from Zebe ; Leku dance from Bukunji ; Wasan Biri dance from Zebe ; Maranji dance from Kosochi.
title: Studies in Nigerian dance

For descriptive notes of parts 1-2, see: Studies in Nigerian dance, no. 1-2.

"Related text: Studies in Nigerian dance, no. 3, Kamberi dances, Peggy Harper. ODU: a journal of west african studies, no. 5, april 1971, institute of african studies, university of ife: nigeria"--Closing credits, no. 3.
